10.02 a.m.

    Mr Lim Choon Mong (Serangoon): Mr Speaker, Sir, last year I spoke on community centres and this year I have to bring this matter up again. I find that community centres run today are not making good use of the money we spend on them. I notice that the Government always cling to the policy of wanting to have advisory committees. They hand-pick their people and allow the community centres to be run by such people. I told the Government last year that community centres run in this manner would never produce good results. I related to them the events right from the beginning, probably in 1953, after they appointed advisory committees which have shown until today very little result. However, Government considered that it was still essential to have community centres run by advisory committees. Another year has elapsed and more advisory committees have been appointed but the net result produced is still negligible.

    I put it to the Government, Sir, that when it comes to community centres, the people feel that they are Government institutions and they feel reluctant to make use of such centres so that today apart from a few little boys making use of them and a little bit of activity like adult education, community centres are really not being used as they should be used. I put it to the Government last year that it should be best that people should be elected to run such centres. We have elections at the Assembly level for the running of the country. We have elections at the City Council level; we will also have elections at the Rural District Council level: yet, with democracy practised at such levels, we deny the people of a small village or a small community the right to choose their own natural leaders to run their little local affairs. This is most unsatisfactory. If

Column: 3305

Government want community centres to be fully utilised, the natural leaders of the people should be chosen to run them so that the people would feel that these centres belong to them and I am sure that community centres would then be properly used. I have put forward schemes as to how this could be achieved but so far I have not had the satisfaction of either seeing the schemes I suggested being implemented or a more workable scheme being put forward by the Government. I urge the Government to consider this matter more fully so that money expended under this head should not be wasted.

    Mr Lee Choon Eng (Queenstown): Mr Speaker, Sir, I am glad that the Government is speeding up the Malayanisation scheme and that the Social Welfare Department is fully malayanised having a local officer as Acting Director of Social Welfare. Sir, this officer who is holding this appointment has quite a considerable knowledge of economics. I understand that he went to the United Kingdom to study this subject but what is most essential, Sir, in this department is that we should have a local man with practical experience rather than a man with a knowledge of economics because social work is such that you come in close contact with the people and you should have a complete knowledge of social work through contact with all communities in Singapore. The present holder of this appointment, I may say, Sir, is more suited in the Chief Minister's Economic Adviser's Department. We want, in fact, a local man to go into this department as an understudy to take over eventually the post of the Economic Adviser instead of an expatriate officer in that department. Shame! If we can malayanise the Social Welfare Department, why can we not malayanise the Economic Adviser's Department as well? Surely, local people can take over such appointments.

    Sir, as I said, this officer went to the United Kingdom for seven years training in economics. He came back two years ago and was attached to this department but what has been the nature of his work in this Department? I understand he was placed on research work

Column: 3306

rather than on the actual function of the department which is social welfare. Now, Sir, within a period of two years in that department doing research work, it would be rather difficult for him to know the practical side of social welfare - the requirements and the needs of the public in connection with social welfare. Social welfare is a very, very complicated problem and it takes time to learn and know the actual needs of the public. As I said it must be done by a man with practical experience. So Government should appoint officers in departments to suit their actual qualifications and the present holder, who is an economist, should go to the Economic Adviser's Department.

    Now, if there is an officer in the Social Welfare Department who has got practical experience. I think he should be appointed to take over that department. It is better to appoint one officer who knows the work rather than to appoint a man who has got all the theory but has not got the practical knowledge in the department and then in the end find that it is difficult to run it. I do hope that the Minister for Labour and Welfare will look into this and see that the Economic Adviser's Department will be malayanised very soon.

    The Assistant Minister to the Chief Secretary (Mr M. P. D. Nair): Sir, as a person who is closely associated with community centres in Singapore, I would like to contribute my experience to this Assembly.

    Sir, in Singapore community development has entered its first stage. During this initial stage, it is very necessary that the management of community centres should be in the hands of advisory committees. Up to now, the advisory committees have been responsible for stimulating the necessary interest of the community to participate actively in their affairs. Sir, this first stage of development has been very successful, in that it has encouraged those interested in community work to come forward to work hard unselfishly.

    Sir, I am told by the Social Welfare Department that the next stage in the development of community centres is in

Column: 3307

the offing. In the rural areas, of course, as we are all aware, it will be the District Councils which will be responsible for the management of community centres and these District Councils are shortly to be composed of an elected majority. I can see that community development in the rural areas will be much more vigorous and enthusiastic once these District Councils come into being and we will then see the elected representatives of the people playing their part in the shaping and in the development of their respective communities.

    Sir, I believe that there is ample room for the development of community centres in Singapore. I do not for a moment think that we have achieved all what we should have achieved in the past two years and I think one of the ways in which we can be actively helpful in the matter of community development is to see that politics do not become part of community development. Sir, there can be great harm done to community development once politics become part of their activities. Community centres are primarily designed to help the community as a whole irrespective of whether they are members of particular political parties and that is one aspect of the essence of community development, that politics should not be the order of the day. I do hope, Sir, that the people who participate actively in community centres will not engage themselves in party politics.

10.15 a.m.

    One other aspect I would like to deal with is the second stage of community development. Community development cannot be a success if one is to think that it is either a Government responsibility or that it is the entire responsibility of the people. Community development must be developed on the basis of the utmost co-operation between Government and the people and then only community development will come to stay in Singapore.

    Sir,I believe that with the coming of the District Councils and the new City Council, the community centres will take

Column: 3308

a new form, have new ideas and a new stimulus and if we all actively participate with the active co-operation of the Government, we will develop community life on the right and proper lines.

    The Minister for Labour and Welfare (Dr Lim Yew Hock): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Member for Serangoon (Mr Lim Choon Mong) himself said that he brought up this subject of community centres last year and this year, he is just repeating what he has said last year. Last year, Sir, I replied to the points raised by him and I think I should not repeat what was said in order not to take up the time of this Assembly unnecessarily but I would refer him to what I said last year.

    With regard to the points raised by the Member for Queenstown (Mr Lee Choon Eng) the officer who is now holding the post of Director of Social Welfare is an officer who has been in that department, if I remember rightly, from the very start when that department was formed after the liberation. He has a very close knowledge of the working of that department. It is true that he is very suitable in the economic field - the only man in the whole civil service who can take over from the present Economic Adviser. But the hon. Member must not forget that in regard to an appointment, this is left to the Public Service Commission. The Government does not post officers into any particular posts. The Government has plans for organising an economic research unit under Dr Goh who will, we hope in due course, take over from the present Economic Adviser.

    Mr Lim Choon Mong: Mr Speaker, Sir, after all that was said last year, I must still express my dissatisfaction that work concerning community centres is still at a standstill. It has been at a standstill for the last two or three years and I do not think that what the Government replied to what I asked last year would be sufficient. I have always told the Government that what we want to see are results and not just words or

Column: 3309

replies. I find that instead of the Assistant Minister for Labour and Welfare replying to what I said, another Assistant Minister, the Assistant Minister to the Chief Secretary, replying to affairs concerning welfare.

    Mr Nair: On a point of clarification, Sir.

    The Chairman: If the hon. Member will give way.

    Mr Lim Choon Mong resumed his seat.

    Mr Nair: Sir, I quite frankly admit that I was not replying and that it was not my responsibility to reply to an item under this particular head. I said at the very beginning of my speech that I was only contributing to this Assembly my experience as a person who is closely associated with community centres.

    Mr Lim Choon Mong: Mr Speaker, Sir, if the Assistant Minister thinks that he is closely associated with community centres, then I think he is not fully versed with the affairs of community centres. He said that party politics should not come into community centres. So far as I know, I have never found it to be so. He said that community centres should be guided at first but I find that those centres which are free from governmental control and set up by the local people themselves progress to a far greater extent than those guided by advisory committees of the Government. Now, Sir, I believe that if Government is not going to put up a scheme whereby greater use is made of community centres, then Government will again fail in this aspect.

    I will now go on, Sir, to further aspects of social welfare work. We know that today in Singapore we have a large number of young people who because of the inadequate educational facilities are on the streets. They are too young to be employed and not educated enough. I believe that the Social Welfare Department can come in to help these people to a very great extent. I must state that they have been helping in this direction but I would like to see more intensified assistance being given to these young people. If the Social

Column: 3310

Welfare Department is not going to take a very active part in shaping the lives of these people and making them into very useful citizens, then I believe that the work will then pass on to other departments of the Government, say, the Police Department and later on the Prisons Department. If we do not spend money for education and for social welfare, then we will have to spend more money on a bigger police force and build more prisons to house criminals. Assistance has been given in this direction but I maintain that it is insufficient. Greater help must come. The young people must be looked after. They will be the citizens of tomorrow and Government should give greater assistance to such people. Even today, Sir, on this question of the problem with the young people, there is one great need and that is boys' hostels. Here again, I find that voluntary organisations are helping to a far greater extent. I refer to the Boys Town. They have done a splendid job. They have places for these young people but I think there are so many other people who want to get in but are unable to do so and Government should give further assistance in this direction. If it were possible, it would even be better if Government should undertake to run such an organisation as Boys Town. I hope that Government will take this into consideration and see that the young people of Singapore are given greater attention than they are being given now.

    Dr Lim Yew Hock: Mr Speaker, Sir, on the points raised by the Member for Serangoon regarding more active help to be given to teenagers and linking this with Boys Town and hostels, may I say this, Sir. The Government is doing every, thing that is possible within the limited means at its disposal. In social work of this kind, it is vital that the public should work hand in hand with the Government and if there are organisations as pointed out by the hon. Member which are keen to play their part to assist the youth of Singapore, I can on behalf of the Government assure such organisations that whatever assistance they may require from the Government in this co-operative work, will always be given

Column: 3311

favourable and sympathetic consideration.

    Question on the amendment put, and negatived.

    Mr Lee Choon Eng: Mr Speaker, Sir, I rise to move,

    That the sum to be allotted for Head 52 be reduced by $10 in respect of subhead 13 therein.

    Sir, subhead 13 refers to "Public Assistance" and comparing the figures to be provided for next year with that for this year, I see that there is an increase of $380,000. This is a very substantial increase.

    Sir, in moving this amendment, I must make it clear that I am not trying to decrease or to reduce the vote. I only move this amendment to initiate a debate because public assistance is very essential in Singapore but what I cannot understand is this, Sir. Why should there be such a substantial increase? Is the Government expecting more unemployment next year? And if not, why should there be an increase then? I paid a compliment to the Government yesterday, Sir, pointing out there was less unemployment this year as compared with last year. So if we can have less unemployment this year, we can definitely have far less unemployment next year. We always look forward to progress and we must move in the forward gear rather than in the reverse gear. Sir, if the Government is not anticipating more unemployment next year, then this increase is not warranted. There should not be any increase. If Government provides more employment for the people, I am quite sure that the vote for "Public Assistance" will not be such a big amount as $6½ million for next year. The question is this: Government must have stability in this country and if Government does not have stability, then there will be more unemployment. It is not a question of providing more and more money for public assistance. It is a question of providing more and more employment which would reduce the number of applicants coming for public assistance. I am quite sure that no one would like to apply for public assistance if he is employed and if he can

Column: 3312

earn a decent living. I am quite sure that a man is forced to submit his application for public assistance through poverty and unemployment. So if Government provides more employment, then there would be less people applying for public assistance. So it is up to Government not to increase the amount required for public assistance but to provide more employment so that less people will be dependent on the charity of the public and the Government.

10.30 a.m.

    Dr Lim Yew Hock: Sir, the increase asked for this particular vote is not because of Government's anticipation of increased unemployment in the next year. The rates are still the same. There is to be no change in the rates next year. The relief granted is not only to the unemployed. It is also granted to the sick and to the aged and, from experience gained in the department, we know that more and more people are coming forward for this relief because they feel that they are qualified to do so. When we first started, it was with a small amount. It was not, shall we say, so popular. It is now becoming very popular to the poor, popular in the sense that they now know that there is a Government which is anxious to look after their welfare, and the fact that they know now that there is somebody to look after their welfare, the more anxious are they to make application for relief.

    Question on the amendment put, and negatived.

    Head 53 -

    Question proposed,

    Mr Lee Choon Eng: Mr Speaker, Sir, under this head, I find that the name given to the Ministry does not cover transport but I take it that the word "Communications" covers transport as well and that it is one of the functions of the Ministry to look into the transport problem.

Column: 3313



    In most countries, as far as I understand, transport is a state responsibility and not run on a commercial enterprise basis but in Singapore I find that it is run by an expatriate firm under a monopoly. Rightly or wrongly, most of the shareholders of that firm are expatriates or British rather than Asians and this monopoly is given to this firm in the name of the Singapore Traction Company. There are also Chinese bus companies running this passenger bus service in Singapore but the competition between these Chinese bus companies and the Singapore Traction Company is out of comparison. There is a move I under, stand to amalgamate all the Chinese bus companies into a big company to compete with this Singapore Traction Company. Whether it will materialise or not is left to be seen.

    At the present moment, the consideration of bus routes is left in the hands of the Transport Advisory Board - that may be the correct name of the Board. I do appreciate that all the members sitting on this Board are experts on transport but they are fully conversant with the theoretical side of the transport problem and not with the practical side. The question of bus routes, I think, should be considered more in the light of the needs and requirements of the public. Sir, the number of vehicles on the roads are increasing day by day. With the new serial lettering "SS" that is coming up, I am quite sure that we will have more vehicles by the end of the year. Car owners are finding it difficult to park their cars with this increase in the number of vehicles on the roads. Practically every road in the city is restricted for parking purposes. You either find a "white line" or a "No Parking" sign on roads within the city area. It is rather fortunate that Members of this Assembly are privileged to have a special car parking space in front of this Assembly House. If not for this privilege, I am sure that Members will also find it difficult to find a place to park their cars when attending sittings of this Assembly. It is my opinion that it is more convenient to come down to the city in taxis than in our own cars. Now, to solve this traffic problem, I think Government should

Column: 3314

consider introducing a light railway scheme. I believe, some years back, the Assistant Minister to the Chief Secretary who was then in the City Council suggested such a scheme. He is now in power and I think he should push this scheme through. This light railway scheme, Sir, could bring workers from the rural areas into the city, and if most of the workers or those who come down to the city for business would travel on small trains, I am quite sure that this would lessen the number of vehicles on the roads. In most countries, there are such light trains which go into the rural areas to convey the people down to work. Sir, I hope that Government will look into this and give consideration to the introduction of such a scheme whereby people can travel to and from the city. This will lessen congestion on the roads as I said and, at the same time, petrol consumption will be less. With the increase of 20 cents tax on a gallon of petrol, I am sure that the public will be quite happy to travel in light trains rather than in their own cars. They can leave their cars at home until the evening when they can then go for their pleasure rides. I sincerely hope that the Assistant Minister to the Chief Secretary who had this in mind some years back will press the Government to introduce such a scheme.

    Mr Goh Chew Chua (Ponggol-Tampenis): Mr Speaker, Sir, may I ask the Minister for Communications and Works whether he is aware that some of the buses in the rural districts are not running uniformly. Some of them run from morning to 12 o'clock midnight and some of them run to 10 p.m. I do not understand why this should be so especially for the rural people, Sir, who, late in the night, find difficulty in getting down to town, especially on emergency cases such as confinement or accident. If the buses run up to 12 o'clock midnight, I think that will give more help to the rural people. So I hope that the Minister for Communications and Works will consider this matter.

Column: 3315



    Mr John Ede (Tanglin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I would just like to add to what the last two speakers have said, that the problem of public transport is very little nearer solution than it was 2½ years ago when the Labour Front stated that their policy was to nationalise transport. There is only a short time left under this head. So I do hope that the Minister will give us a resume of what is the intention of the Government in the last few months of its life.

    The Minister for Communications and Works (Mr Francis Thomas): With regard to transport, Mr Speaker, Sir, I have already made a statement in the course of this Budget debate. I presume that some Members were out of the room at that time. They will get a copy in due course of what I said and they can see what my remarks were: they can also get it from their friends. So I do not think that I need say it again.

    With regard to the point raised by the Member for Ponggol-Tampenis (Mr Goh Chew Chua) that buses are running irregularly, I am aware of that problem. It is a complex problem which is derived partly from managerial inefficiency perhaps and partly from stresses and strains between employer and employee. When some workers dislike the management they do sometimes get the buses driven wrongly. In effect, they do not exactly go slow, but go in a muddled way; you get five buses close together on the roads and they pass the bus stops at the same time and then for half an hour after that there is no further bus. That kind of thing does occur.

    But, generally speaking, it is a problem derived from the long and muddled history of public transport with which I have had to grapple because it had been badly done in the past. It is a complicated job. We could, no doubt, have made a Ceylon approach to the problem and gone with great rapidity and passed laws - not provided money - and set up a Board. Whether or not that would, in fact, have brought any improvement remains to be seen. My own judgment is that it is much better to accept delay and to make sure that you are going forward over sound

Column: 3316

foundations than to say, "This is a bad situation and I assume that any action will make it better." You have got to get the right kind of action or you may merely make it worse. But we are in fact considering now whether it is possible to do anything interim about the bus services, particularly the rural bus services and the Chairman of the Rural Board has been pressing on this matter for some time. I hope that as soon as this Budget is out of the way, my Permanent Secretary can attend to other work and he will be able to get on with this one.

    Now, for the Member for Queenstown (Mr Lee Choon Eng). As usual, he took a good deal of our time to say nothing of any importance at all. He knows a good deal about bus companies because he was or is still a City Councillor -

    Mr Lee Choon Eng: Until tonight.

    Mr Francis Thomas: - and was closely concerned with them for a number of years and knows a good deal about them but if he know about the workings of this House, he would know that in this House, we have already passed an Omnibus Services Licensing Authority; not a Traffic Advisory Board, but an authority with the duties and powers properly laid down and constituted by this House. It was typical of the approach which he makes to this House that he should not even know what he is talking about and talk about a Traffic Advisory Board.

    The light railway scheme is, of course, a very old chestnut. I have got lengthy reports which have been brought up to date since I was a Minister in my office and, of course, it would be worth considering but the capital cost would be enormous. Even using relatively vacant land, the mere fact that you have got either to lift the thing up in the air or run it down in the ground - foundations and that kind of thing - makes it a very difficult thing to carry out and highly speculative, particularly if the main work of development is not on the present line of the railway. If you are going to run a railway from Collyer Quay to

Column: 3317

Katong, the hon. Member can imagine the amount of cost that would be involved.

    Mr John Ede rose -

    The Chairman: Order. Time has elapsed.

    Mr Lee Choon Eng: Mr Speaker, Sir, speaking on this subject, I do exactly know what I am speaking about because this is from my own practical experience.

    I believe that the function of this department is to study the atmospheric movements, with special emphasis on weather forecasts. From my experience, I emphasise again that the forecasts given by this department sometimes go wrong. Before big social functions, I understand that some hosts do contact the department to ascertain the actual weather forecasts for the day but as I have said, some of the forecasts given by the department go wrong. A forecast is given as "fine" for the evening and when the host is entertaining his guests in the evening, there is a big downpour or a big shower. So I think that there must be something wrong in that department. I am afraid I do not know where the fault in the department lies as I am not in that department. I can only speak of what I actually know, that the forecasts have sometimes gone wrong. So if there is something that has gone wrong in that department, I hope the Minister will look into it and find out where the fault is or what is wrong and let us know whether he can remedy the faults or right the wrongs of that department

Column: 3318



    Mr Francis Thomas: Of course, the difficulty for the Meteorological Department, Mr Speaker, Sir, is that Singapore is surrounded by water and by relatively undeveloped areas and countries from which meteorological reports are not directly available. Even in Great Britain, which is a highly developed area, you still get mistakes over what is going to happen to the weather; whether it is going to rain tomorrow; or whether you are going to have light showers or heavy showers. Because what, in fact, the meteorological people can do is to check up on the clouds and the speed they are approaching, the height they are at and the type of cloud and all the factors involved and say, "It looks as though the result of this and this and this added together means a shower of rain in Katong." But the shower of rain may, of course, by some factor they have not completely been able to evaluate, fall on the sea instead or fall on Queenstown perhaps. However, I do not think that there is anything wrong with the department. I think it is a very good department. Its main function, of course, is not to provide information for V.I.P. tea parties but to advise the ships and aircraft which are in our meteorological area and to give them the best warning it can as to what sort of weather conditions they are likely to meet with. It is a safety-of-life service. It may give a safety-of-tea party service on the side as far as it can, but that is not its proper function. We are hoping to have the storm warning radar in use (it is now being erected) and this will give a further degree of reliable information but I do not think at any time in the foreseeable future will Singapore be able to say with absolute reliability precisely where and when rain will fall.

    Question put, and agreed to.
